thread.title: Friends motorcycle through India
thread.title_full: Friends motorcycle through India | News Local

author: Bev Jordan
title: Friends motorcycle through India

organizations.name: lizanne perry photography hills shire friends

text:
Ride for Rights Ben Butcher, 21 (Pymble), Scott Grills, 25, (Baulkham Hills) and Cameron Perry, 25 (West Pennant Hills) are heading to India Credit: Lizanne Perry Photography Hills Shire Friends gear up for Ride for Rights documentary to help kids in India Bev Jordan, 8, 2017 2:13pm
A group of four young friends will be riding motorbikes across India and filming their journey to raise awareness of children living in poverty.
Cameron Perry from West Pennant Hills said his eyes were open to the desperate plight of young children when he visited India for the first time in 2015 and was there for three months.
This time the 25-year-old is returning with friends Scott Grills and Taylor Hogan, 25 and videographer Ben Butcher, 21.
media_camera Fourth Ride for Rights Rider is Taylor Hogan, 25
Their Ride for Rights starts on February 24 and will taken them an estimated 8000km along the route they will be filming on the work if the Indian charity called CRY (Child’s Rights and You www.cry.org).
Cameron Perry said: “With the support of CRY, we have the opportunity to visit and meet with the children and leaders at different projects across India, from the urban slums in Delhi to projects in rural Rajasthan.”
He said the charity was building schools and running training programs which they wanted to highlight in their documentary.
“We really want to support these children and give them a chance to achieve their dreams.”
Mr Perry said seeing a teenage street child on his first trip had been the spark for the trip.
“He was running a street stall and was the happiest and most hardworking person. He wanted to be a nurse but he hadn’t been to school.
“I would love to see someone with that much drive able to achieve their dream.”
Scott Grills from Baulkham Hills said it was about bringing hope to the children they met.
“We want to raise awareness but we also want to inspire other people step out of their (comfort zone),” he said.
If you want to get involved, support their campaign or watch their journey visit
https://www.chuffed.org/project/rideforrights
